TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive Ustic Haplocryepts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Pergrin gravelly sandy loam, on a northeast aspect of 10 percent slope, lodgepole pine at 9,440 feet.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
Oe-1 inch to 0; intermediately decomposed coniferous leaf litter.
E--0 to 9 inches; light gray (10YR 7/2) gravelly sandy loam, brown (10YR 4/3) moist; single grain; loose, nonsticky, nonplastic; common fine roots; 20 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobble; slightly acid; clear smooth boundary.  (5 to 12 inches thick)
Bw--9 to 17 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) very gravelly sandy loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/6) moist; single grain; loose, nonsticky, nonplastic; few fine roots; 35 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobble; slightly acid; clear smooth boundary.  (7 to 14 inches thick)
C--17 to 23 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) very gravelly loamy sand, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/6) moist; single grain; loose, nonsticky, nonplastic; few fine roots; 40 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobble; neutral; abrupt irregular boundary.  (5 to 14 inches thick)
Cr--23 to 31 inches; weathering granite grus.
R--31 inches; hard granite.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Saguache County, Colorado; NW 1/4 SW 1/4, Sec. 20, T. 48 N., R. 8 E.  U.S.G.S. Poncha Pass quad.; Lat. 38 degrees, 23 minutes, 48 seconds to 24 minutes, 01 second N.; and Long. 106 degrees, 6 minutes, 46 seconds to 7 minutes, 03 seconds W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Mean annual soil temperature ranges from 36 to 38 degrees F., and mean summer soil temperatures range from 40 to 42 degrees F.  Depth to bedrock ranges from 20 to 40 inches.  The thickness of the solum ranges from 16 to 40 inches.  Clay content of the particle-size control section averages 6 to 18 percent.  The soil is noncalcareous throughout, and soil reaction ranges from moderately acid through neutral.  Rock fragments average 35 to 60 percent in the particle-size control section and are pebble sized, but in some pedons up to 50 percent may be stones.  The soil moisture control section is dry in some part less than one-half the time when the soil temperature is greater than 41 degrees F.
The E horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value 6 or 7 dry, 4 through 6 moist, and chroma of 2 or 3.
The Bw horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value 5 through 7 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 6.  Texture is commonly sandy loam or loam.
The C horizon, if present, has a hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value 5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist, chroma of 2 through 6.  It is commonly loamy sand, sandy loam or loam.

COMPETING SERIES.content:
COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Alpinepeak (ID), Blackleed (MT), Ellena (MT), Elve (MT), Evaro (MT), Firada (MT), Frindle (AK), Garlet (MT), Gromes (NM), Hiore (MT), Hughes (AK), Ketchum (ID), Longhike (NV), Losee (UT), Murial (NV), Nambe (NM), Poso (ID), Rubick (MT), Scout (UT), Shadow (MT), Storm (CO), Taglake (WY), Targhee (ID), and Yankeefork (ID) series.
Alpinepeak, Blackleed, Elve, Evaro, Garlet, Hiore, Gromes, Ketchum, Losee, Nambe, Poso, Rubick, Scout, Shadow, Storm, and Taglake soils lack bedrock above 40 inches.
Ellena soils have rock fragments in the particle-size control section that are mostly cobbles.
Firada soil has a consistent k horizon above the bedrock.  Frindle soil has a thin mantle of volcanic ash.  Hughes soils lack bedrock above 40 inches, but have a 2C horizon of very stony silt loam at 10 to 20 inches.
Longhike soils are dry in all parts of the soil moisture control section for 45 or more consecutive days from late July to October.  (Zeric moisture regime.)
Murial soils are 20 to 40 inches deep over calcareous siltstone.
Targhee soils are usually moist when the soil temperature at 20 inches is greater than 41 degrees F.  Yankeefork soils lack bedrock above 40 inches and also have sandy-skeletal materials in the C horizon at 28 to 60 inches.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Pergrin soils are on mountain backslopes and ridges.  Elevation ranges from 9,000 to 11,600 feet.  Slopes range from 10 to 60 percent.  Pergrin soil formed in residuum or colluvium derived dominantly from granite or igneous volcanic materials, and sandstone.  The mean annual precipitation ranges from 20 to 30 inches.  Mean annual air temperatures range from 34 to 38 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Granile, Agneston, Seitz, Hechtman, and the Scout soils.  Granile, Seitz, and Agneston soils have a zone of clay accumulation in the subsoil, and the Scout soil is more than 40 inches to bedrock.  Hechtman soil has bedrock at less than 20 inches.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium to rapid runoff; moderately rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  This soil is used for timber production, wildlife habitat, recreation, watershed, and summer range.  Vegetation is lodgepole pine, subalpine fir, Engelmann spruce, seral aspen, kinnikinnick, common juniper, and scattered grasses and forbs.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Pergrin soil is of moderate extent in southwestern Colorado.

REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Rio Grande National Forest (West Part); Saguache County, Colorado.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  This series name was formerly called Peregrine.  Diagnostic horizons and features recognized are:  an ochric epipedon; a cambic horizon from 9 to 17 inches; more than 35 percent rock fragments in the texture control section; 6 to 18 percent clay in the texture control section; hard bedrock at 31 inches; a cryic temperature regime.
